resource.chars:
MEET RICHMOND DEFEAT
W. AND L. NAVY IN
FIRST GAMES

Maryland’s varsity basket ball
team that got off to a flying start
by beating Washington and Lee, 40
to 27, and Navy, 21 to 12, in its
two games prior to the Christmas
holidays, will resume action tonight
by entertaining the University of
Richmond five in Ritchie gymna-
sium .
Richmond will not be easy prey
and the Old Liners will have to be
on their mettle to get the long end
of the count. The team from the
Old Dominion capital is a veteran
one, all of the players of the suc-
cessful combination of last season
again being available and Frank
Dobson, their coach, is well versed
in the court game.
Make Great Start
The Old Liners’ veteran outfit
showed to good advantage in the
triumph over Navy that caused the
critics along the Atlantic Seaboard
to sit up and take notice. In fact,
the Marylanders got recognition in
the New York paper-, some of the
experts going so far as to say that
the Terrapin team probably was the
best in the East. The Gotham
writers saw Navy nose out Colum-
bi, a good quint, and they con-
cluded that Maryland must be “hot”
to go over to Annapolis and trim
the Midshipmen.

Maryland did play a great all-
around game against Navy and
with Ensor having a field day by
registering 17 points, was in the
van all the way. Faber got the
other markers. Ensor’s collection
came from five court goals and 7
out of 9 tries from the foul line.
However, it was the clever team-
work and defensive play that told.
Navy’s 12 points was the lowest
ever scored by a Midshipmen basket
ball team.
The Old Liners started Faber and
Ensor at forwards, Supplee at cen-
ter, and Beatty and Cardwell at
guards against Navy. Boyd, who
played in the place of Faber for a
while, was the only substitution.
W. and L. Easy
Maryland used practically the
whole squad in the Washington and
Lee contest, starting a reserve com-
bination with the exception of Card-
well at guard. Troxell and Adams,
forwards; Llnkous, center, and
Whelchel and Cardwell, guards be-
gan the clash, but seven others got
into the fray before the finish.
Faber, Ensor, Supplee, Boyd,
Stevens, Beatty and Woodward
were the others to see action, some
of the regulars being rushed in
when Washington and Lee got off
to a four point lead. This was the
only time the Generals were in the
van,as the Old Liners soon forged
to the front and stayed there, mix-
ing reserves and regulars all the
way and never having the complete
full team in the game.
Tonight’s game will be the last
home clash until Gallaudet visits
on Wednesday, January 20, as the
tossers will leave on a jaunt into
Virginia tomorrow for three games
in four days. V. M. I. and Wash-
ington and Lee will be met at
Lexington tomorrow and Thursday
nights, respectively and after rest-
tackle Virginia Poly at Blacksburg
ing Friday, the Old Liners will
Saturday.
U. of M.
